Name: Hydrogen
Notes: Prices of hydrogen produced by distributed steam methane reforming, as predicted by H2A Production Model from United States Department of Energy,[7] assuming price of natural gas of 3 USD/MMBtu (10 USD/MWh; 0.10 USD/m3). Does not include cost of storage and distribution.

Name: Deuterium
Notes: 99.8% pure compressed deuterium gas, in lot size of 850 L (142 g). Also sold by same supplier in the form of heavy water at price of 3940 USD per kg deuterium.[10]
In 2016 Iran sold 32 tons of heavy water to United States for 1336 USD per kg deuterium.[11]

Name: Helium
Notes: Crude helium sold to non-government users in United States in 2018. In the same year, stockpiles of US government helium were sold on auctions for average price of 0.00989 USD/L.[13]

Name: Lithium
Notes: See also: Lithium as an investment
Min. 99% pure.

Name: Beryllium
Notes: Min. 99% pure.

Name: Boron
Notes: In the form of boric acid, price per boron contained. Min. 99% pure.

Name: Carbon
Notes: See also: Diamonds as an investment

In the form of anthracite, price per carbon contained, assuming 90% carbon content. There is a wide variation of price of carbon depending on its form. Lower ranks of coal can be less expensive, for example sub-bituminous coal can cost around 0.038 USD/kg carbon.[17] Graphite flakes can cost around 0.9 USD/kg carbon.[18] Price of synthetic industrial diamond for grinding and polishing can range from 1200 to 13300 USD/kg, while cost per weight of large synthetic diamonds for industrial applications can be on the order of million dollars per kilogram.[19]

Name: Chlorine
Notes: As chlorine is manufactured together with sodium hydroxide in chloralkali process, relative demand for one product changes the price for the other. When demand for sodium hydroxide is relatively high, chlorine price can fall to arbitrarily low levels, even to zero.[28]

Name: Astatine
USD/L[c]: Only under a tenth of microgram of astatine has ever been produced.[42] Most stable isotope has half-life of 8.1 hours.

Name: Radon
USD/L[c]: Used in brachytherapy until 1960s,[57] currently radon is not used commercially.[58]

Name: Francium
USD/L[c]: Only quantities of the order of millions of atoms have been obtained for research.[59] Most stable isotope, 223Fr, has half-life of 22 minutes. Francium has no commercial or medical uses.[58]

Name: Radium
USD/L[c]: Radium was historically used in the treatment of cancer, but stopped being used when more effective treatments were introduced. As medical facilities had to pay for its disposal, its price can be considered negative.[60]

Name: Thorium
Notes: As 99.9% pure thorium oxide, price per thorium contained. Free on Board port of entry, duty paid.

Name: Protactinium
USD/L[c]: In 1959–1961 Great Britain Atomic Energy Authority produced 125 g of 99.9% pure protactinium at a cost of $500000, giving the cost of 4000000 USD per kg.[42] Periodic Table of Elements at Los Alamos National Laboratory website at one point listed protactinium-231 as available from Oak Ridge National Laboratory at a price of 280000 USD/kg.[62]

Name: Uranium
Notes: See also: Uranium market
Mainly as triuranium octoxide, price per uranium contained.

Name: Neptunium
Notes: Periodic Table published by Pomona College Chemistry Department lists neptunium-237 as available from Oak Ridge National Laboratory at 660 USD/g plus packing costs.

Name: Plutonium-239
Notes: Certified reference material sample in the form of plutonium(IV) oxide, price per plutonium-239 contained.

Name: Americium-241
Notes: Available from Oak Ridge National Laboratory as reported in Nuclear Weapons FAQ.

Name: Einsteinium
USD/L[c]: Only microgram quantities have ever been produced.[42] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 471.7 days.

Name: Fermium
USD/L[c]: Only tracer amounts have ever been produced.[42][67]:13.2.6. Most stable known isotope has half-life of 100.5 days.

Name: Mendelevium
USD/L[c]: Only around 106 atoms have been produced in experiments.[67]:13.3.6. Most stable known isotope isotope has half-life of 51 days.

Name: Nobelium
USD/L[c]: Only around 105 atoms have been produced in experiments.[67]:13.4.6. Most stable known isotope has half-life of 58 minutes.

Name: Lawrencium
USD/L[c]: Only around 1000 atoms have been produced in experiments.[67]:13.5.6. Most stable known isotope has half-life of 11 hours.

Name: Rutherfordium
USD/L[c]: Only a few thousand atoms have been produced in experiments.[42] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 2.5 hours.

Name: Dubnium
USD/L[c]: Atoms of dubnium have been prepared experimentally at a rate of at most one per minute.[68] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 29 hours.

Name: Seaborgium
USD/L[c]: Only tens of atoms have been produced in experiments.[69] The most stable known isotope has half-life of 14 minutes.

Name: Bohrium
USD/L[c]: Only tens of atoms have been produced in experiments.[70] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 1 minute.

Name: Hassium
USD/L[c]: Only tens of atoms have been produced in experiments.[70] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 16 seconds.

Name: Meitnerium
USD/L[c]: Only produced in experiments on a per-atom basis.[71] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 8 seconds.

Name: Darmstadtium
USD/L[c]: Only produced in experiments on a per-atom basis.[71] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 9.6 seconds.

Name: Roentgenium
USD/L[c]: Only produced in experiments on a per-atom basis.[71] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 2.1 minutes.

Name: Copernicium
USD/L[c]: Only tens of atoms have been produced in experiments.[70] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 29 seconds.

Name: Nihonium
USD/L[c]: As of 2015, less than 100 atoms have been produced in experiments.[72] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 8 seconds.

Name: Flerovium
USD/L[c]: As of 2015, less than 100 atoms have been produced in experiments.[72] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 1.9 seconds.

Name: Moscovium
USD/L[c]: As of 2015, less than 100 atoms have been produced in experiments.[72] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 0.65 seconds.

Name: Livermorium
USD/L[c]: As of 2015, less than 100 atoms have been produced in experiments.[72] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 53 ms.

Name: Tennessine
USD/L[c]: As of 2015, less than 100 atoms have been produced in experiments.[72] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 51 ms.

Name: Oganesson
USD/L[c]: As of 2015, less than ten atoms have been produced in experiments.[72] Most stable known isotope has half-life of 0.7 ms.
